overview_of_class: The course will be devoted entirely to reading Hamlet - or, as we will come to see, the proliferation of Hamlets that have emerged since its/their  first performances and publication around 1600.  We will read the three early, distinct printed versions of the play (1603-1623), and we will read intensively in the editorial and critical approaches that have sought to address what is/what has become the mystery of the play, its text(s), its central character(s?), and its function(s) in criticism, the canon, and culture more generally: psychoanalytic Hamlet, post-structuralist Hamlet, Marxist Hamlet, new historicist Hamlet, feminist and queer Hamlets, New Bibliographical and new textualist Hamlets, alongside the critical perspectives of some film versions and Stoppard's revision.  "To be or not to be," as we will see, is not the only question.
name: Studies in Shakespeare
subject: ENGLISH
